How do you define a net-zero building in operation?

At @COP28_UAE, almost 30 countries pledged their commitment to what the @UN is calling the â€˜Buildings Breakthroughâ€™. Almost 40% of global energy related emissions come from buildings. https://t.co/7yFntSaeSf
The aim of the commitment is to modernise the global building sector by making near-zero emissions and climate resilient buildings the new normal by 2030.

If this is to happen, we urgently need to agree a single, global definition for net zero buildings; one the whole building development, design and construction value chain can get behind and use to drive rapid decarbonisation.

Primary care physicians (PCPs) are often the first line of defense against chronic kidney disease (CKD) for their patients. PCP Dr. Kevin Fernando shares his insights on the importance of testing patients for CKD. https://t.co/0fkHmjWVOu

In its early stages, patients with CKD usually do not show symptoms. And, fewer than 10% of people are aware of their disease. As a result, patients are often not diagnosed until the disease has significantly progressed. https://t.co/wV6P6fHGMM
PCPs have a direct line to some of the most at-risk patients. By testing CKD risk factors such as diabetes or hypertension, PCPs can detect CKD early and slow disease progression.
Urine Albumin-to-Creatinine Ratio (UACR) and Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) tests are two simple ways to detect CKD in patients. https://t.co/BKBIrltCxa
Albuminuria (an increased excretion of urinary albumin) is a marker of kidney damage. Testing albuminuria is recommended for patients at risk for CKD.
One of the easiest ways to test for albuminuria is through urine albumin-to-creatinine (UACR) testing, which can be done with a simple spot urine sample.

To calculate UACR, you just need to divide albumin concentration in milligrams by creatinine concentration in grams and follow the chart linked here to define any abnormalities. https://t.co/d8W9RBITT9

The second test is eGFR which shows the percentage of kidney functions remaining in patients. This test can be included in a patientsâ€™ blood and metabolic screenings and the results can help track kidney function over time.

This chart provides further information on the classification of CKD based on the degree of both kidney function (measured by eGFR) and kidney damage (measured by UACR) present. https://t.co/lq6mv6qZLW
The KDIGO CKD evaluation and management guidelines are a particularly helpful tool to gain a deeper understanding of early identification and intervention of CKD. https://t.co/m8uKb8ssf7
Early diagnosis changes lives. It can mean fewer complications, slowed disease progression, and importantly a better quality of life for patients. https://t.co/28MAH1Mttn

Hyperkalaemia (HK) can be a serious, chronic condition where potassium levels in the blood are higher than normal and it is often associated with heart failure (HF). https://t.co/VUSOsJEKqQ

A HK diagnosis can sometimes prevent patients with HF from achieving guideline recommended RAASi therapy.

But evolving science shows HK can be managed, allowing RAASi therapy to be maintained in patients with both HF and HK.

We're working to address the unique needs of cardiorenal patients living with HK by advancing research to help patients optimise treatment options.

Hyperkalaemia (HK) can be a recurring condition in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), and new data are revealing how a HK event is associated with CKD progression. #ASN2023 https://t.co/APaoqPebkW

A new dual-country real-world evidence study found that risk of progression to kidney failure is over 70% higher in CKD patients who discontinued RAASi therapy after a HK event compared to patients who remained on this lifesaving therapy.
Patients with CKD that maintain RAASi after an episode of HK have improved outcomes. Learn more about HK: https://t.co/vJvDBoDWGp #ASN2023

Cement is made in two stages. 

Stage 1 â¡ï¸ Materials are heated in a kiln to create clinker. 

Stage 2 â¡ï¸ The clinker is mixed with other ingredients to make the final product. The chemical reaction which creates clinker is what causes the immense carbon footprint of cement. https://t.co/j2juSkh2DV
Thatâ€™s why our solution focuses on producing less CO2 by manufacturing #LowCarbonCement with lower levels of clinker content.

At approximately what age does the adult immune system become depleted of the resilience built up in youth?
@i_am_kisslay Thank you for making us aware of this content.  This is not genuine GSK content and is the subject of ongoing legal proceedings.

From the age of about 20 onwards, the immune system begins to change gradually in a process known as age-related decline in immunity, or immunosenescence.

https://t.co/eq5Tjqsosv

The resilience built in youth gradually depletes until around 50 years of age, when the risk of infection and more serious outcomes increases.

Find out more about age-related decline in immunity on Behind the Science ğŸ‘‰https://t.co/eq5Tjqsosv

#DYK what primary biliary cholangitis (#PBC) is?

The correct answer is B. 

#PBC is a rare autoimmune liver disease which can be associated with debilitating itch and poor quality of life.
In people with #PBC, severe cholestatic pruritus, a debilitating liver-related itch, significantly correlates with poorer quality of life, similar to advanced Parkinsonâ€™s disease.

Chronic liver disease can lead to physical burdens and social stigma, and itâ€™s one of the most common causes of death worldwide. 

This week, weâ€™re at #EASLCongress talking about how weâ€™re getting ahead of liver disease together.

Maersk is deeply concerned about the incident involving the MAERSK GIBRALTAR while the vessel was traveling from Salalah, Oman to Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. The crew & vessel are reported safe. We are currently working to ascertain the full details of the incident. Vessel was not hit

A number of circulating posts are depicting the tragic Maersk Honam fire incident in 2018. Due to sensitivity and accuracy we wish to clarify the images and videos in question are unrelated and do not represent the event that transpired yesterday. The Maersk Gibraltar was not hit

We understand the emotional impact of both incidents and provide this clarification to dispel confusion and spread of misinformation. The recent attacks on commercial vessels in the Bab al-Mandab Strait are alarming and pose a significant threat to the safety & lives of seafarers
This issue cannot be addressed by the global shipping industry alone, and we urge the international society to come together to find a swift resolution to bring the situation under control.

@13orangesbc @shellenberger @Benfogle @thecoastguy @TonyClimate 1/4 Weâ€™re deeply concerned about the East Coast whale strandings. While vessel strikes and fishing gear entanglements are the leading cause of whale deaths in the US, the foremost threat to marine life, including whale populations, is a warming ocean caused by a changing climate.

@13orangesbc @shellenberger @Benfogle @thecoastguy @TonyClimate 2/4 The Marine Mammal Commission, the NOAA and the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management have reported no link between recent strandings and offshore wind survey activity. The industry is subject to the most stringent level of protections for marine mammals and protected species.

@13orangesbc @shellenberger @Benfogle @thecoastguy @TonyClimate 3/4 Surveys, construction, and operations are reviewed by several agencies and subject to protective conditions, incl. vessel speeds, time of year restrictions, and mandatory observers on vessels. @lang_psy Unfortunately, this is based on a mistake. There is too little electricity from renewable energy on the market and too much fossil import. The increased demand after 2021 will be exacerbated by the war in Ukraine. The price is rising due to the gap.

@martinsadleder @BastibotI We simply don't have enough electricity for everyone, at any time. Therefore, the electricity is sold to the highest bidder at the price determined by supply and demand. Those who produce cheaper than this price make a profit. 1/
@martinsadleder @BastibotI But only until other market participants expand their production and also offer it at these costs. That is competition. 2/

@martinsadleder @BastibotI We have a gap in the electricity market between domestic renewable energy and demand. This has to be covered with imported electricity or gas power - at a much higher price. This stimulates the market to invest more in renewables and dampens the price. 3/3

@martinsadleder @BastibotI The anger is understandable, which is why we are trying to clear things up here. Austria has been dependent on electricity imports for 20 years. As long as it was cheap, it was hardly noticeable. Now this gap is making itself painfully apparent and is forcing us to boost our expansion - wherever we are allowed.

@schulrategger Long-term contracts are necessary in the industry in order to calculate prices in the long term. This has nothing to do with "speculation".
As far as we are concerned: we are largely in public hands, but that is probably already known. https://t.co/lI9xkHQjsV

@lang_psy Legal certainty and accelerated procedures would be a start for the accelerated expansion of renewable energy. That's easy to tweet, but in practice it's an enormous challenge. Interventions in the market won't result in a single additional wind turbine being built.

@dinischwab @bastiboti Yes, we have been dependent on imports for many years. Since 2021, due to the demand for gas and the war in Ukraine, imported electricity has become enormously more expensive - and now determines the domestic market price.
https://t.co/5DyO9oF96P

@werni007 @schulrategger Nobody benefits in the long term from high electricity prices. Local customers, households and industry need a lot of electricity. We distribute most of the profits to the public sector and invest in renewables - wherever we are allowed to. https://t.co/BxmnXShicE

@bastiboti @dinusschwab We sold at market prices. We are not allowed to ask for more (abuse of market power) or less (disloyalty). Any profits are either distributed or invested, because the root cause is too little production from renewables.
@IdealismPrevail How about: capital for investments in the energy transition (assuming the legal situation allows it).
@JohannesSpalj Wait a minute! Please remain respectful despite all the outrage.

@netzverwalter This is emergency aid for serious cases and we know that it does not solve the problem. The bottom line is: we have too little electricity from renewable energies. Keynote speaker @maurerchr in #morningtalk: #MeritOrder sounded like a "perfidious" order, but it is only a model. The electricity market, which has a bad reputation in political circles, worked, as the securing of supplies to France last winter showed. https://t.co/77UWW2Z8Ol

Every megawatt hour saved has saved generation from price-setting gas-fired power plants. High prices also provide the right incentives to balance out imbalances in the market - e.g. investment in PV @maurerchr in #morningtalk

CEO Strugl: Removing price signals from the market would mean dampening the incentive to invest. If a price signal reduces scarcity, it makes energy saving attractive and encourages investment in renewables. #Morgengespraech https://t.co/0alfe4n2LV

@AKoppl: The Commission has taken the right path by focusing on investments, but the effect is medium-term. There is still potential in the proposal to increase the benefits for consumers. This also requires strengthening the network infrastructure. #Morgengespraech https://t.co/TuxSy555Jc

CEO Strugl in #morningconversation: The "Contract for Difference" would limit the flexibility of pumped storage power plants with a quasi-fixed price. Such restrictions unsettle investments and thus the mobilization of private capital for the #energytransition

@AKoppl: Distortions like last year cannot be ruled out. Interventions in short-term consumer prices will be necessary. The dynamics triggered (inflation!) are difficult to get under control. #MorningConversation

JÃ¼rgen Wahl from #EXAA on the topic of risk: The stock exchange functions as a marketplace. There are a variety of (certified) partners on the stock exchange. With direct marketing with a single partner, the risk of failure increases. #Morgengespraech https://t.co/qL4dezdbpO

@PeterMolnarEE From the #morningconversation: The market itself worked. The collateral consequences were and are sometimes harsh. Accompanying instruments are included in the Commission's proposal, but only a comprehensive expansion of renewables will really improve things.

CEO Strugl in the #morningconversation on security: A one-year price guarantee, for example, is included in the proposal. The most important building block is sufficient production. If there is a lot of supply on the market, prices fall. That's why the answer is: massive expansion of renewables.

@PeterMolnarEE Only as long as gas is needed. Austria also imports an average of 10% of its electricity per year. With each new wind turbine, the number of hours in which expensive gas determines the price decreases.

Many thanks to our guests and especially to @corinnamilborn for the excellent #morningtalk moderation!

@johanneskopf We are looking for a legally secure solution for both providers and customers. At the moment, this is only really possible with the active consent of the customers. With our offer, we offer a fair price without a contractual obligation - so you can cancel at any time.
@martin38990815 No, we are looking for a legally secure solution for both providers and customers. At the moment, this is only really possible with the active consent of the customers.

@yvebiskupska Consumers fear price increases, and it is also risky for providers not to have legal certainty for customer contracts. We therefore chose what we believe to be a fairly priced, attractive offer with a price guarantee but the option to cancel at any time.

Historian and author Philipp Blom opened today's #INSPIRE conference day with his keynote speech, emphasizing the lack of future scenarios and analyzing the unusual form of hope. https://t.co/QB5GWCc3t2

"We do not have realistic scenarios for the future - that is not enough. A democracy that does not look ahead will crumble. How can we give hope to our societies? Hope is a strange animal. Hope is not the optimism that everything will be fine.
But the indispensable will to do something because it is important. It is time for our society to think boldly, much more boldly than our politicians do."

Renowned author Marc Elsberg then explained the importance of ideas and their narratives: "At the beginning of change, we need ideas about what the future should look like. But we also have to be able to formulate these ideas so that the world understands them." https://t.co/BAN3sC7HJT

â€œWe need to think about our narratives to shape the future.â€

Brigitte Bach @AITtomorrow2day presents current research results on the need for flexibility in the electricity sector at #Inspire Energy Talk: The greatest increase in the need for flexibility is in very short-term and seasonal flexibility. https://t.co/aOYxXu7vt9

Good news for hydropower: Climate change is not leading to a decline in production, but rather to a profile shift from summer to winter. In terms of consumption, the need for heat is reduced, but the need for cooling is increasing, says Brigitte Bach @AITtomorrow2day #Inspire

Lack of infrastructure is expensive: @GChristiner ner @apg_at mentions 150 million euros in costs in 2023 just due to a lack of network infrastructure for flexibility. And yet: there is no business case for flexibility products on the electricity market in Austria. #Inspire https://t.co/Qq4LZOJIwC

CEO Michael Strugl: Germany has a concrete, comprehensive strategy to accelerate storage expansion - including the duration of the process. "That's how it has to be done." #Inspire https://t.co/qb3VKP81nH

Brigitte Bach @AITtomorrow2day: We will not be able to avoid large-scale technical solutions, central storage facilities are also needed, specifically: large batteries, hydrogen storage. This requires rapid market integration and market design. #Inspire

According to @GChristiner @apg_at, there is still a lot to do in the distribution network to address the flexibility there (home storage, electric cars). Without this, there is no incentive for private customers to make their infrastructure available. #Inspire

We will need all options because they offer different levels of flexibility. It might have been wiser to push for storage instead of the PV expansion that is already taking place. "I would be in favor of subsidizing storage," says CEO Strugl. #Inspire

CEO Strugl: Pumped storage power plants will continue to be successful in the market in the future when other forms of storage enter the market, because demand will grow with the expansion: from currently 60 GW to 500 GW by 2050 #Inspire
